title: The Case of the Wobbly Geometry Gala
summary: The Geometry Gala decorations are a mess: frames are crooked, angles are mislabeled, and the butterfly banner got mirrored wrong on purpose. Solve four geometry clues (perimeter, area, angles, symmetry) to catch the goofball.

introLetter.subjectLine: HELP. The Geometry Gala is tonight and the SHAPES are doing crimes.
bodyParagraphs: Tonight is the annual Geometry Gala (very fancy, very sparkly, and very “please do not lick the exhibits”).

But this morning, someone swapped our perfect decorations for wobbly impostors. The perimeter fence is missing a chunk (or… is it?), the stage blueprint has been “optimized” by a raccoon with a marker, the angle posters are labeled with absolute lies, and the giant butterfly banner is definitely NOT symmetrical—one of the judges dropped their clipboard straight into the punch bowl.
Three suspects were spotted carrying rulers and giggling like cartoon villains.
Please solve the clues before the gala begins and the triangle tries to run for mayor.
introLetter.signature:
Sincerely,
Curator Prism McShimmer
(Director of Shapes, Keeper of the Very Serious Protractor)

postmark.stampSlogan: Goofington Postal Service: We Deliver Mail. The Shapes Deliver CHAOS.

suspects.name: Duchess Diagonal

alibi.claim: Symmetry is easy. The butterfly banner is totally symmetrical… horizontally.
alibi.note: Butterflies usually mirror left/right, not top/bottom. Hmmm.

quips: I only cut things diagonally. It’s a lifestyle.
If you see a straight line… no you didn’t.

suspects.name: Professor Angleton

alibi.claim: That big wide angle? Very acute. Extremely acute. The acutest.
alibi.note: Overconfidence detected. Possibly powered by protractor fumes.

quips: I don’t make mistakes. I make ‘alternate realities’.

suspects.name: Captain Perimeter Pete

alibi.claim: The fence walk is 22 steps around. I counted. Twice. While eating a hotdog.
alibi.note: Counting while hotdogging is historically unreliable.

quips: Perimeter is just a hug for a shape.
I measure things with confidence, not accuracy.
My tape measure is named Gerald. Gerald is judgey.

locations.name: The Museum of Extremely Serious Shapes
locations.description: Sparkly exhibits, velvet ropes, and one suspiciously sticky protractor.

locations.name: The Gala Stage (currently wobbly)
locations.description: Blueprints on the floor, confetti everywhere, and a rectangle acting innocent.

locations.name: Banner Hall of Symmetry (now in chaos)
locations.description: A giant butterfly banner that looks like it sneezed halfway through being printed.

evidence.label: Gerald’s Tape-Measure Receipt
evidence.description: A crinkled strip of tape with segment lengths marked in angry little numbers.

evidence.label: Blueprint Smudge of Doom
evidence.description: A rectangle blueprint with coffee stains and the words ‘AREA?? PERIMETER?? VIBES??’.

evidence.label: Bubble-Wrapped Protractor Print
evidence.description: A protractor impression… plus bubbles popped at exactly the wrong angles.

evidence.label: Mirror Smear Sticker
evidence.description: A handprint on a tiny mirror. Someone tested symmetry… aggressively.

puzzles.title: Fence Walk of Doom
puzzles.prompt: Walk the fence segments and find the total perimeter.

ui.introLine: Count each side. No teleporting. No wormholes.
successQuips: Perimeter captured! The fence stops screaming.
You measured it so cleanly the fence lines look jealous.
Gerald the tape measure snaps back into its case with a proud *zip*.
failQuips: That’s not the perimeter… that’s a *perim-eh-ter*.
You missed a side. Or invented one. Either way: chaos.

hints: Perimeter means the distance *around* the shape.
Try tapping each segment in order to make a scratch total.

puzzles.title: Stage Blueprint Builder
puzzles.prompt: Build a rectangle stage with the correct area (and maybe perimeter).

ui.introLine: Pick rows and columns. Make the stage legal for dancing.
successQuips: Blueprint approved! The stage stops wobbling (mostly).
Area achieved. Perimeter satisfied. Geometry feels seen.
failQuips: Area is off. The dancers are sliding into the void.
Nice rectangle, but the blueprint whispers ‘NO’.

hints: Area of a rectangle = rows × columns.
If a perimeter rule appears, perimeter = 2 × (rows + columns).
Try factor pairs for the target area (like 4×6 for 24).

puzzles.title: Poster of Lying Angles
puzzles.prompt: Label each angle as acute, right, or obtuse.

ui.introLine: Angles can’t all be acute, Professor.
successQuips: Angle truth restored! The posters quit playing tricks on your eyeballs.
You classified angles with the confidence of a wizard.
failQuips: The angle disagrees and files a complaint.

hints: Obtuse is more than 90° (wide and comfy).

rounds.prompt: This angle is small and pointy. What is it?
This angle is a perfect corner. What is it?
This angle is wide enough to park a tiny scooter in. What is it?

puzzles.title: Butterfly Banner Symmetry Scan
puzzles.prompt: Pick the line of symmetry (or admit there is none).

ui.introLine: Find the mirror line. Try not to smudge the glitter.
successQuips: Symmetry secured! The banner stops looking insulted.
Perfect mirror line. The doodle feels balanced.
Nice! Even the mirror is impressed.
failQuips: Nope—now it’s extra lopsided. The mirror sighs.
The doodle is still lopsided. It’s judging you.

hints: A line of symmetry splits a shape into two matching halves.
Try folding it in your mind (or imagine a mirror).
Some shapes have no symmetry at all — that’s allowed.

rounds.prompt: Which mirror line makes the butterfly match itself?
This staircase doodle: does it have a mirror line?
Which mirror line makes the kite match itself?

finalQuestion.question: Who sabotaged the Geometry Gala with wobbly labels and chaotic shapes?
correctRationale: The protractor print shows the wide angle is obtuse, but Professor Angleton insisted it was ‘very acute’.
The angle posters were mislabeled in the same confident handwriting style as his ‘alternate realities’.
Once the angle lies were fixed, the rest of the decorations matched the official museum records.

lines: Duchess Diagonal said ‘horizontal symmetry’ for the butterfly, which is wrong…
…but the biggest sabotage was the angle labels, and that points to someone else.
Perimeter Pete counted the fence wrong, sure…
…but the gala didn’t collapse until the angles were labeled with lies.

correct.headline: CASE CLOSED: The Angles Were Gaslit!
bodyParagraphs: You slam the evidence on the table (gently, because it’s a museum table).
Professor Angleton’s ‘acute obtuse’ labeling scheme collapses instantly under the power of a correctly used protractor.
He tries to escape by turning sideways (like a very thin rectangle), but security politely escorts him into the Gift Shop of Consequences.
The Geometry Gala proceeds safely. The butterfly banner forgives everyone. The triangle does NOT become mayor.

incorrect.headline: WRONG SUSPECT: The Shapes Continue Their Crimes
bodyParagraphs: Your accusation echoes across the museum… and the angles laugh.
Try again—one suspect’s story doesn’t match the geometry evidence.

badges.name: Geo Detective
badges.description: Solved the Wobbly Geometry Gala without letting the triangle run for office.
